Addresses a number of compatibility issues with different tilesets that have been reported by users. See the git log or issues for details.

The new loaders empowers rendering frameworks to visualize various geospatial datasets.

The ArrowJS dependency has been upgraded to v0.16.
The ArrowJS API documentation in the loaders.gl website has been improved.
Images can now be loaded as data: Using the
with width, height and a typed array containing the image data (instead of an opaque
The streaming JSON loader now has an experimental option
that returns the top-level JSON object containing the JSON array being streamed, as additional first (partial) and last (complete) batches.

The 2.0 release brings potentially dramatic bundle size savings through dynamic loading of loaders and workers, significant overhauls to several loaders including , image loading improvements and the glTF loader, and a powerful loader composition system.

Each loader now defines its own sub object in the options object. This makes it possible to cleanly specify options for multiple loaders at the same time. This is helpful when loaders.gl auto-selects a pre-registered loader or when passing options to a sub-loader when using a composite loader.
that use large libraries (e.g. WASM/WebAssembly or emscripten/C++ transpiled to JavaScript) now load those libraries dynamically from
CDN resulting in dramatic bundle size savings. E.g the bundle size impact of the
was reduced from > 1MB to just over 10KB.
Ease-of-use: Worker loading is provided by the main loader objects. It is not necessary to import the
objects to enable worker loading (but see below about bundle size)
Performance: Loading on worker threads is now the default: All worker enabled loaders now run on worker threads by default (set
to disable worker-thread loading and run the loader on the main thread).
Debugging: Development builds of workers are now available on
CDN, eabling debugging of worker loaders.
Bundle size: Workers are no longer bundled, but loaded from from the
Bundle size: Note that the old
classes are still available. Using these can save even more bundle space since during tree-shaking since they do not depend on the non-worker parser.
to be composed from more primitive loaders without losing the ability to run some parts on worker, pass arguments to sub-loaders etc.
(Experimental) A new module for the basis format that enables. This module also provides a
that supports batched (i.e. streaming) parsing from standard JSON files, e.g. geojson. No need to reformat your files as line delimited JSON.
is now a "composite loader". The perhaps most important change is that
also loads all sub-assets, including images, Draco compressed meshes, etc making the loaded data easier for applications to use.
see below for a list of changes

now ensures HTML images are completely decoded and ready to be used when the image is returned (by calling
Since the type of images returned by the
option, a set of functions are provided to work portably with loaded images:
Separate API to work with unparsed images in binary data form:

can signficantly simplify loading of arrays of arrays of (mipmapped) images that are often used in 3D applications. These methods allow an entire complex of images (e.g. 6 cube faces with 10 mip images each) to be loaded using a single async call.
More image test cases are now run in both browser and Node.js and a couple of important Node.js issues were uncovered and fixed.
The 1.3 release is focused on production quality 3D tiles support, maturing the v2 glTF parser, and provides some improvements to the core API.
, and no longer needs to be copied from the loaders.gl
tiles can now be loaded and displayed by the
object which tracks the loading process to help profile big tilesets.
Easily displayed in your UI via the
class now cancels loads for not-yet loaded tiles that are no longer in view).
Scheduling dramatically improves loading performance when panning/zooming through large tilesets.
Select the new glTF parser by passing
Many improvements to the v2 glTF parser.
The loader selection mechanism is now exposed to apps through the new
Loaders can now examine the first bytes of a file
This complements the existing URL extension based auto detection mechanisms.
Now reuses worker threads. Performance gains by avoiding worker startup overhead.
Worker threads are named, easy to track in debugger
Worker based loaders can now call
recursively to delegate parsing of embedded data (e.g. glTF, Draco) to other loaders
The 1.2 release is a smaller release that resolves various issues encountered while using 1.1.
: File Type Auto Detection now supports binary files
: Image file extensions now added to loader object
: Generate default sampler parameters if none provided in gltf file
Support for dynamic traversal of 3D tilesets (automatically loads and unloads tiles based on viewer position and view frustum).
Support for loading tilesets from Cesium ION servers.
Auto centering of view based on tileset bounding volumes
The 1.1 release addresses a number of gaps in original loaders.gl release, introduces the
objects (from drag and drop or file selection dialogs).
function - can now accept a MIME type as second argument.
function ( EW) - returns the MIME type of the image in the supplied
function - can now accept a MIME type as second argument.
The glTF module has been refactored with the aim of simplifying the loaded data and orthogonalizing the API.
"Embedded' GLB data (GLBs inside other binary formats) can now be parsed (e.g. the glTF parser can now extract embedded glTF inside 3D tile files).
class (NEW) - A helper class that provides methods for structured access to and modification/creation of glTF data.
function ( EW) - Function that performs a set of transformations on loaded glTF data that simplify application processing.
- loader/writer pair that enables loading/saving custom (non-glTF) data in the binary GLB format.
Support for the 3D tiles format is being developed in the new
Loading of individual point cloud tiles, including support for Draco compression and compact color formats such as RGB565 is supported.
before use. This reduces the number of dependencies, bundle size and potential build complications when using other loaders.gl modules when not using Node.js support.
Helper functions for loaders have been broken out from
